title-group.article-title: The Demographic Transition and the Sexual Division of Labor

contrib-group.aff: Catholic University of Rio de Janeiro, National Bureau of Economic Research, and Institute for the Study of Labor

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2008 by The University of Chicago. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: This paper presents a theory in which increases in female labor force participation and reductions in the gender‐wage gap are generated as part of a single process of demographic transition, initially characterized by reductions in mortality and fertility. The paper suggests a relationship between gains in life expectancy and changes in the role of women in society that has not been identified before in the literature. Mortality reductions affect the incentives of individuals to invest in human capital and to have children, with implications for female labor force participation and the wage differential between men and women. The paper also presents some empirical evidence to support the predictions of the theory.

fn.p: This paper benefited from comments from Roger Betancourt, Suzanne Bianchi, Matthias Doepke, William N. Evans, Pedro Cavalcanti Ferreira, David Meltzer, Canice Prendergast (the editor), Samuel Pessôa, Seth Sanders, two anonymous referees, and seminar participants at CEDEPLAR‐UFMG, Ibmec‐Rio, Simon Fraser University, Stockholm School of Economics, University College London, University of California, Santa Barbara, University of California, Santa Cruz, University of Michigan–Ann Arbor, Yale University, the Harvard Program on the Global Demography of Aging conference on “Population Aging and Economic Growth,” the Stanford Institute for International Studies conference on “Health, Demographics, and Economic Development,” the Institute for the Study of Labor/European University Institute Workshop on “Demographic Change and Secular Transitions in Labor Markets,” the 2005 meeting of the Brazilian Econometric Society, and the 2006 meeting of the Society for Economic Dynamics. Soares gratefully acknowledges financial support from the National Institutes of Health (NICHD grant HD050520‐01). The usual disclaimer applies.

Expressing the Problem in Terms of Time Shares
Characterizing the Optimal Choice and Effects on Allocation of Time
sec.p: In the figure, we assume that the two curves intersect. If they did not, the origin would be the optimal choice. Points II and III are the ones that satisfy the first‐order conditions.
Proposition 2. Point III is preferable to point II and therefore is the solution to the household problem.
